Award.AwardTitle: Improved water resources sustainability utilizing multi-time scale streamflow forecasts

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
0756269
Arumugam

This project has three major objectives. The first is to develop an integrated approach to promote sustainable management of water supply systems through combined application of both weather information-based near-term streamflow forecasts and climate-based short-term streamflow forecasts. For this first objective, water management measures will be invoked that include water conservation and hedging, water contracts for improving water-use efficiency, in-stream and ecological flow protection and alternative water management plans including wastewater reuse. The second major objective is to apply and demonstrate the approach for two water supply systems, one serving an area experiencing rapid increase in water demand in North Carolina, and another aimed at maximizing hydropower production and preserving ecological flows in Virginia. The third major objective is to develop an instructional tool for assessing the role of proactive water management measures and multi-time scale forecasts to promote sustainable water management and to incorporate it in undergraduate/graduate curricula at several universities. An educational outreach effort will inculcate dynamic risk management and sustainability concepts in water and environmental curricula at two major historically black colleges in North Carolina.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main intent of this project is to reduce the uncertainty in multi-time scale forecasts (weekly to seasonal), and to utilize them for improving water and ecological sustainability over selected watersheds.  

The primary contribution from the project on multi-time scale forecasting is on the proposed methodology for reducing the uncertainty in medium-range (15-day ahead) forecasts by combining disaggregated climate forecasts and 15-day ahead weather forecasts. The proposed methodology was demonstrated to reduce the uncertainty in 15-day ahead precipitation forecasts for each biweekly period over the entire continental US. The study also contributed to reducing the hydrological model uncertainty by evaluating the performance of each candidate model conditioned on the relevant predictors. Perhaps the most fundamental contribution from this study is the demonstration of why multimodel combination reduces uncertainty in streamflow forecasts by systematically considering the measurement and model structural uncertainties. Findings from the supplemental award include quantification of how changes in land use control the changes in streamflow.  For this purpose, small watersheds in NC with no reservoirs were considered and the changes in the indicators of hydrologic alterations (IHA) were computed over two defined periods having significant land-use development. The study found that changes in the annual maximum peak flows are pretty significant due to land-use development, whereas changes in the monthly flows primarily arise due to changes in climate.

The project also addressed several fundamental questions related to the utility of seasonal streamflow forecasts in improving water and ecological sustainability.  In this regard, a reservoir optimization model was formulated that can effectively develop strategies of reservoir releases to reduce downstream flow alterations. For this purpose, Philpott Lake in the Roanoke River basin was considered to demonstrate how the reservoir could be operated in minimizing the downstream ecological impacts without compromising the water supply and hydropower needs utilizing streamflow forecasts.  The study also investigated how streamflow forecasts could be utilized for improving inter-basin transfer between Neuse and Cape Fear River Basins in the Triangle area in NC. Findings from the study include that both covariability in initial conditions of the reservoirs and inflows determine the utility of streamflow forecasts in facilitating inter-basin transfer. For instance, forecasts are more beneficial in facilitating inter-basin transfer for basins that experience negatively correlated initial conditions which indicates higher initial conditions in one reservoir coincide with lower initial conditions in another reservoir.  Application of seasonal climate forecasts for improving Neuse and Cape Fear River basins show that the entire NC triangle area could benefit by utilizing streamflow forecasts for facilitating the inter-basin transfer between the two reservoirs (Falls Lake and Lake Jordan) to improve regional water sustainability.

 

Three PhD students were supported from this study.  Two journal articles are already published and another three articles are under review. Findings were also demonstrated and presented in leading conferences such as AGU and ASCE-EWRI proceedings. This project also helped the PI in securing his NSF CAREER award. Findings from the study were included in both undergraduate and graduate courses offered by the PI and co-PI at NCSU. Modules developed for these courses were also shared with other young faculties who are establishing their career on water and environmental sustainability.
